DataElement.preferredName: Malignant Neoplasm Intratumoral Morphology Heterogeneous Status
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Text term to describe the status of the intratumoral morphologic heterogeneity.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A tumor composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues.  Malignant neoplasms usually metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision.  The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas (adenocarcinomas or squamous cell carcinomas), Hodgkin's and non-Hodgkin's lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas. -- 2004_Within a tumor._Morphology is the form and structure of organisms (plants, animals, and other forms of life), or of their parts, and the study or science of the same._The quality or state of consisting of elements that are not of the same kind or nature.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A tumor composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues.  Malignant neoplasms usually metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision.  The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas (adenocarcinomas or squamous cell carcinomas), Hodgkin's and non-Hodgkin's lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas. -- 2004

Concepts.definition: A neoplasm composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues. Malignant neoplasms often metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision. The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas, Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas.

Property.preferredDefinition: Within a tumor.:Morphology is the form and structure of organisms (plants, animals, and other forms of life), or of their parts, and the study or science of the same.:The quality or state of consisting of elements that are not of the same kind or nature.

Concepts.definition: The science of the form and structure of organisms (plants, animals, and other forms of life), or of their parts, and the study or science of the same.  In pathology, the specific appearance of cells and tissues (normal and abnormal) under the light or electron microscope.
The quality or state of consisting of elements that are not of the same kind or nature.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: indication of the presence and extent of disease.
